(1 comment)
link this properly.

Main difference

 - No requirements to fit into IPMI util sensors.
   - Can only be percent able type. phosphor-dbus-interface only support percentage that's in ipmi util sensors related to health.
   
 - interfaces will not be modeled for ipmi sensors.
 - Targeting redfish??
 - Focus on Software metrics.

---
 
 - Maybe duplicate metrics from phosphor-health-monitoring?
   - Hardward metric -> phosphor-health-monitoring
   - Software metrics in this.
Done
Done

Adding "Bytes" to phosphor-dbus-interfaces was rejected
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/51779

Only physical sensor types are modeled in phosphor-dbus-interfaces and phosphor-health-monitor is "bound to" using sensors, thus causing a deadlock. So the progress to do what is proposed in this proposal to support the types of metrics that can't be expressed as "utilization sensors" (regardless of as part of phosphor-health-monitor or a new daemon)
Updated with new info inside the doc

Prefer polling? instead on-demand fetching.

- Maybe some metrics will need to be on-demand, with majority be polling.
Done

DBus data bandwidth is about 4 MB/s or ~5K messages per second as one of our previous experiments.

For small message sizes, # of messages per second is the limiting factor.
For large message sizes, bandwidth is the limiting factor.

If DBus is not sufficient, we can pass a file descriptor to the consumer, similarly to phosphor-debug-collector

In my understanding: "lightweight" in terms of "obtaining metrics" being a self-sufficient task, similar to the collector daemon in "schedviz", or "traced" in Perfetto. Obtaining metrics doesn't need to be designed to, or be limited to be IPMI-compatible like phosphor-health-monitor.

fetching metrics

`GetMetrics` method with vector of string and return vector variant.

Instead just GetAllMetrics or get single metrics.

---
Daemon same as metrics?
Done

Object objects should be linked by association definition.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HuLFb-rE7pyHZMo7hyL9312BENvSqXzRjOArJq0CMP8/edit?resourcekey=0-4rK69vPijZUEfr2Cc_GIHA#

ok, didn't mean to link that.

I meant https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/architecture/object-mapper.md#associations
Done
Need some conversations on this
Done
This is WIP still so I'm not going to give any score.  Wanted to give some early feedback though.
Adding my view of the current limitations of phosphor-health-monitor
Thank you! This is really helpful.
The format needs to be fixed. Take a look at the template about column limit
Done
I suspect it would be useful to compare and contrast the telemetry implementation too.
Done, If there is more important info that I missed, I would be happy to add more
I don't think this is true.

To be more specific:
* Sensors read through ipmitool can have ranges beyond 0~255, but their values are still "quantized to 8-bit". They are still a one-to-one linear or non-linear mapping between [0x00~0xFF] and the configured range, with 256 distinct values.
* phosphor-health-monitor's DBus objects are all Sensors. They are also now made compatible to `ipmitool`, so users will expect them to be IPMI-compliant.

I'm still not following what limitation the IPMI handlers causing them to be quantized imposes on phosphor-health-monitor (and all other providers of sensors).

> They are also now made compatible to `ipmitool`, so users will expect them to be 
IPMI-compliant.

"expect them to be"?  If we have some requirements here on sensors, I must not know what they are, and we should get them documented in phosphor-dbus-interfaces.  I don't know why IPMI would be imposing requirements on other pieces of code.  I personally don't care about IPMI on my systems.
This has been updated to show the special circumstances of the Utilization Sensors and the intent behind phosphor-health-monitor. If this is wrong or misleading, then I would be happy to fix it.
any concern on this?
This is certainly not true since we have Utilization sensors already.

Utilization sensors alone does not free p-h-m from the burdens of from physical sensors enough so as to be able to cover all kinds of metrics, such as kb/s, bytes, and "number of open file descriptors", etc.

And also, even if we get rid of the limit on units, only scalar values are supported in Sensor.Values, so we still can't export graphs, spans, binary blobs, etc.

> Utilization sensors alone does not free p-h-m from the burdens of from physical sensors enough so as to be able to cover all kinds of metrics, such as kb/s, bytes, and "number of open file descriptors", etc.

There is no requirement that PHM implements exclusively Sensor.Value objects either though.

> And also, even if we get rid of the limit on units, only scalar values are supported in Sensor.Values, so we still can't export graphs, spans, binary blobs, etc.

Three comments:

1. Can you point me to a definition of "Metric" that you're using in this context?  I don't understand what a "binary blob metric" is.  I'm slightly concerned you're using the word Metric in a Company-Specific way that nobody else is reading into this document.

2. This response leads me to believe we are missing a "Use Case" very early in this document.  What are you trying to solve with a "Metric Collector", from a user perspective, that isn't solved already?

3. I sure hope we're not trying to propose a "I want to store any arbitrary thing in a random KV-store interface and have it exposed on dbus" because that isn't going to fly.  I still expect to see well-documented and programmatically useful interface.  Arbitrary string-referenced fields isn't acceptable.  If we need to propose new interfaces to satisfy what you need, let's do it.

Updated the document to include the special circumstances of utilization sensors

1. Metric is now defined in the doc. I will further clarify if needed.
2. The use case has been made much more explicit. This is a good point that i will need to put much more emphasis on
3. No the requirements have been updated to prevent this from happening.
Considering both of the restrictions above are false you might want to revisit this... ;)

The problem is "not all metrics could be modeled by sensors", so we will either add "non-sensor metrics" to phosphor-health-monitor, or create this new daemon.

The "real restriction" is how phosphor-health-monitor appears to be trapped and self-limited with IPMI compatiblity which corroborates the fact that it must use xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Value interfaces, and in this proposal, we are looking for a way to model and make use of metric data without this restriction.

> The "real restriction" is how phosphor-health-monitor appears to be trapped and self-limited with IPMI compatiblity which corroborates the fact that it must use xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Value interfaces, and in this proposal, we are looking for a way to model and make use of metric data without this restriction.

As mentioned above, I'm not sure what "trap" this is.  I could very well be forgetting though.
Updated the restrictions, please take another look. Thank you!
Where are the details of these "built-in implementations of scraping metrics". I thought they are important to this design.
Updated the problem descriptions. How they are implemented is not important to the design. This establishes how the metrics that are scraped are exported to dbus.
Done

This is fundamentally the reason why things like "Bytes" were rejected from the Sensors implementation.  We don't allow arbitrary strings on dbus like this.  You have no programmatic way to (at compile time) know what "properties" are going to be available between daemons and what they mean.  They're all just trust-me-human strings that we plop in code somewhere and this doesn't scale.

You need to use either real dbus enumerations or interfaces to represent the constructs you want to represent.
Real dbus interface proposal is linked in newest patch. The "arbitrary string" must always be a property of the dbus interface xyz.openbmc_project.Metric.
yeah, all the metrics won't be arbitrary string and will be defined like in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/59504.
Please make sure the dbus interfaces you are proposing have a corresponding proposal in phosphor-dbus-interfaces.  We can't go forward with a design until we see an initial stab at those.
will do
Done
how so?
Added more info on it
measures
Done
rm
Done
rm trailing white spaces and add line break to fit the line limit.
Done
nit: add offset here after the linebreak.
nit: no need for this..
Done
Done
do we know why this is the case?
Removed as a specific example: collectd is shown below.

I guess this depends on how often we scrap the metrics.

I think we will need a way to configure how often each metrics are fetched, but I am not sure if that should be mentioned in the doc.
I feel as this is up to implementation of each metric. This would be way too specific to any one metric or metric type to be part of this design

just want to mention if we will have variable refresh time. Maybe just a json config that we can change at runtime...


However, that would mean that we kind of need to know what metrics we are collected. Maybe that's fine since we would know the time sensitive/expensive metrics anyway.
Ack
Is the purpose for just system metrics?  All BMC firmware metrics? I think the name metric collector might be too generic.  It could be confused with other host related telemetry.

It would be nice to support storing some set of timestamped metrics instead of the latest cached metric value.  The metric collector might sample at a higher frequency, and some downstream exporter will read in a batch from the metric collector at lower frequency, saves on dbus transactions.

what kind of collector are we thinking about.

We are focusing on having exporting the metrics via redfish, and in that context the timestamped metrics might not be fetched if we only expose the metric in one redfish resource. Or we need to propose new redfish schema to support this.

having timestamped metrics is fine and doesn't affect too much of anything, but having
> storing some set of timestamped metrics instead of the latest cached metric value

may not be needed based on what client is requesting the info.
Also want to add that Telemetry service exists and timestamping can be done using OnPeriodic reports.

> Also want to add that Telemetry service exists and timestamping can be done using OnPeriodic reports.

Right, if this process is going to keep historical records (which I would call Telemetry) and not instantaneous snapshots (which I would call Metrics), we should leverage the existing telemetry service.

What are the expected use cases? Reading metrics one by one over dbus seems really inefficient.  Is the use case for some client to only care about one or two of a metric?  Or is it more likely to want to read a subset or even the entirety?  A collector would want to read an entirety potentially.  If there are different collection frequencies then a more sophisticated collection methods need to be supported on the interface.

There was an interested discussion back in 2018 on how to collect metrics
https://lists.ozlabs.org/pipermail/openbmc/2017-December/thread.html#10063
https://lists.ozlabs.org/pipermail/openbmc/2018-January/thread.html#10288
(or https://lore.kernel.org/openbmc/?q=Metrics+vs+Logging)

It's not as relevant today, doesn't discuss Redfish.  But the points about reliability of the collection daemon, graceful failures are still valid.

If clients wish to obtain the latest cached metric, then they would be able to do so by querying the dbus. 

The telemetry service itself could be used along side this daemon to scrape from the dbus and have any metric reports created by Telemetry to be visible within Redfish.

Thanks for pointing out that what I thought were the limitations of phosphor-health-monitor are not real limitations, I'll clarify accordingly, to improve the signal-to-noise ratio in this discussion.
"at the large scale".  I don't know what this means.
Ack
`/proc`?
punctuation
Done
Done
"port bandwidth" doesn't sound like a software-based metric.  Isn't it already covered by EthernetInterface?
Ack. It isnt a software-based metric but the ones we do want to expose are generic ports, not necessary ethernet interfaces.

This is not true.  You're coupling the discussion about the dbus-interface for Sensor.Value with the implementation in P-H-M.  These are two separate design elements.  I see no problem with implementing your proposed metrics in P-H-M.

Thanks for the explanation. It was me that brought this view into this document and misled the direction of this document.

Good to know that implementing the proposed metrics in p-h-m is an option we could consider -- is figuring out details on how the proposed metrics can be integrated p-h-m a way to move this proposal forward?

Is this a 2?  Is this a 3?  I don't know how this is related to #1.

Does systemd provide this?  If so, there is a way for a user, it just isn't exposed over Redfish.

I'm not 100% convinced that we should take data that is already exposed by systemd interfaces and massage them into another dbus format.
Updated the PHM section. Changed the section to display characteristics instead of restrictions. The purpose of the design doc has changed from an alternative of PHM to an addition to PHM
This is the same thing you wrote in #1 just worded differently.  Again, Sensor.Value != "general purpose metrics".

Same as above, it was my understanding of p-h-m that I told Edward about, and now we know general purpose metrics need not be Sensor.Value, the one biggest obstacle I thought exists is no longer an obstacle.
Again, this was about the dbus interface for Sensor.Value.
Same as above.

Why or why not?  I don't understand the argument for or against a particular daemon.  It seems like P-H-M already has logic for reacting to various out-of-bounds conditions, so I don't see any reason to not extend this for some other software conditions you've mentioned here and in your proposed dbus interface.
Same as above.

I feel like the words "telemetry" and "metrics" are often used differently by different companies and in different contexts.  I'm not convinced by a single sentence at the end of a 3 paragraph sentence as having drawn a sufficient logical conclusion.
The point of this section was to explain how telemetry could be used in conjunction with the daemon. I think this last sentence is just out of place. Removed

Why would it be overloading this "daemon"?  It doesn't have to be in a single daemon but it could be a separate daemon in this same repository, right?

I am not sure what you mean by "without a design for a user of this daemon to reference"?  Are you saying that existing code isn't documented to your standards and you don't want to mess with it?  That's a poor rationale for an entirely new daemon/repository in my opinion.
I meant to use this section as a reason not to put the daemon in phosphor-debug-collector. Since now that we decided that PHM is the right place for the daemon to reside, this section is obsolete.
This does not sound like a requirement.
Same as above as this sentence was written under the assumption that p-h-m could only include Sensor.Values.
At what speed is "periodically"?  How do you ensure you're not creating too much noise and performance on dbus since you're at a minimum exposing a new object for each process on the BMC?
They are modifyable via json configs (discussed below). The JSON configs can be used to scrape low-priority metrics less often to limit noise.
nit: interface(s)
Done
I think we _do_ want to limit it.  We're just limiting it to your proposed interfaces from the Metric namespace (+ required associations).
Ack. Deleted since 5 covers this
This is just a wordy way of saying that you have dbus interfaces that return cached data, right?
Yes. I just wanted to express that there will be no delay in metric scraping when querying for them.
So you are limiting the types. ;)

How is it "more lightweight"?  It sounds significantly heavier.  P-H-M currently looks at like 1 or 2 APIs.  You've now got metrics spanning all over the place between sysfs, proc, and systemd.

Please don't use unsubstantiated adjectives to make your proposal sound better.
Ack. Updated the description
nit: process, for example
Ack
nit: JSON.

You mentioned 'files' here and I hope it is files (plural).  I think we have too many examples of a giant JSON config file which is really hard to customize without copying the entire thing, in which case you're left exposed to not gaining new features.
Yes files is plural.
Ack

How was this measured?
How do you know you're going to be better?
This section is obsolete now that the purpose of the design has changed. But it was measured using top on both collectd and local version of this program
How many dbus objects, how often are they updated?  The impacts of the signals might not be small.
On a locally tested machine, there are roughly 150 dbus objects updated every 10 seconds.
Friendly ping
